The problem of computing the mixed volume of convex bodies is also important for combinatorics and algebraic geometry [7]. For instance, the number of toric solutions to a system of nğ‘›nitalic_n polynomial equations on ğ‚nsuperscriptğ‚ğ‘›{{\bf C}}^{n}bold_C start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is upper bounded byâ€”and for a generic system, equal toâ€”the mixed volume of the Newton polytopes of the the corresponding polynomials. This remarkable result, called the BKK Theorem, is covered, for instance, in [25] and [5]).

1.1 Previous Work

The BKK Theorem created an â€œindustryâ€ of computing (exactly) the mixed volume of integer polytopes and its various generalizations; most algorithms in the area are of exponential runing time ([18],[9], [11] and many more). Most researchers in the â€œindustryâ€ donâ€™t bother to formally write down the complexity, rather they describe the actual amount of the computer time. Although there was a substantial algorithmic activity on the mixed volume of polytopes prior to [7], the paper [7] was the first, to our knowledge, systematic complexity-theoretic study in the area. It followed naturally upon the famous FPRAS algorithms [6] for volumes of convex bodies, solved several natural problems and posed many important hard questions. The existence of FPRAS for the mixed volume even for polytopes or ellipsoids is still an open problem.

Efficient polynomial-time probabilistic algorithms that approximate the mixed volume extremely tightly (within a (1+Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilonitalic_Ïµ) factor) were developed for some classes of well-presented convex bodies [7]. The algorithms in [7] are based on the multivariate polynomial interpolation and work if and only if the number kğ‘˜kitalic_k of distinct convex sets in the tuple ğŠğŠ{\bf K}bold_K is â€œsmallâ€, i.e. k=Oâ¢(logâ¡(n))ğ‘˜ğ‘‚ğ‘›k=O(\log(n))italic_k = italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_n ) ).
The first efficient probabilistic algorithm that provides a nOâ¢(n)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚ğ‘›n^{O(n)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-factor approximation for arbitrary well-presented proper convex bodies was obtained by Barvinok [2]. Barvinokâ€™s algorithms start by replacing convex bodies with ellipsoids. This first step already gives nOâ¢(n)superscriptğ‘›ğ‘‚ğ‘›n^{O(n)}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_O ( italic_n ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT-factor in the worst case. The question of existence of an efficient deterministic algorithm for approximating the mixed volume of arbitrary well-presented proper convex bodies with an error depending only on the dimension was posed in [7]. The authors quote a lower bound (BÃ¡rÃ¡ny and FÃ¼redi bound) [1] of (Î©â¢(nlogâ¡n))n2superscriptÎ©ğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘›2\left(\Omega\left(\frac{n}{\log n}\right)\right)^{\frac{n}{2}}( roman_Î© ( divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_log italic_n end_ARG ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT for the approximation factor of such an algorithm. The approximation of the mixed discriminant has also been relaxed to a convex optimization problem (geometric programming). 2.3 Comparison with previous results

The inequality (3) is an analogue of the famous Van der Waerden conjecture [21], proved in [10] and [8], on the permanent of doubly-stochastic matrices. Indeed, consider the â€œboxesâ€ Ki={(x1,â€¦,xn):0â‰¤xjâ‰¤Aâ¢(i,j),1â‰¤jâ‰¤n}subscriptğ¾ğ‘–conditional-setsubscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›formulae-sequence0subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘—ğ´ğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘—ğ‘›K_{i}=\{(x_{1},...,x_{n}):0\leq x_{j}\leq A(i,j),1\leq j\leq n\}italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = { ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) : 0 â‰¤ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â‰¤ italic_A ( italic_i , italic_j ) , 1 â‰¤ italic_j â‰¤ italic_n }. Then the mixed volume is equal to the permanent,

Vâ¢(ğŠ)=Vâ¢(K1,â€¦,Kn)=Pâ¢eâ¢râ¢mâ¢(A),ğ‘‰ğŠğ‘‰subscriptğ¾1â€¦subscriptğ¾ğ‘›ğ‘ƒğ‘’ğ‘Ÿğ‘šğ´V({\bf K})=V(K_{1},\ldots,K_{n})=Perm(A),italic_V ( bold_K ) = italic_V ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = italic_P italic_e italic_r italic_m ( italic_A ) ,

and if the nÃ—nğ‘›ğ‘›n\times nitalic_n Ã— italic_n matrix Ağ´Aitalic_A is doubly-stochastic then Câ¢aâ¢pâ¢(VğŠ)=1ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‰ğŠ1Cap(V_{{\bf K}})=1italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 1.

Though this mixed volume representation of the permanent has been known since the publication of [8] if not earlier, the author is not aware of any attempts prior to the present paper to generalize the Van der Waerden conjecture to the mixed volume. We think that our version, stated in terms of the capacity, is most natural and useful.

The inequality (10) is an analogue of Schrijverâ€™s lower bound [27], [17] on the number of perfect matchings in kğ‘˜kitalic_k-regular bipartite graphs: affine dimensions play role of the degrees of vertices.

The reader familiar with [17] can recognize the similarity between inequalities (9), (3), (10) and the corresponding inequalities in [17], proved for H-Stable polynomials. The method of proof in the present paper is also similar to the one in [17] (in spite of the fact that not all Minkowski polynomials VğŠsubscriptğ‘‰ğŠV_{{\bf K}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are H-Stable). But we get worse constants: for instance, if k=2ğ‘˜2k=2italic_k = 2, in the notation of (10), then in the H-Stable case we get the factor 2âˆ’n+1superscript2ğ‘›12^{-n+1}2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT instead of the 12â¢(1+2)2âˆ’n12superscript122ğ‘›\frac{1}{2}(1+\sqrt{2})^{2-n}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 1 + square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 - italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT obtained in this paper. Whether the latter factor is asymptotically sharp is an open problem.

2.4 The idea of our proof

Our proof of Bapatâ€™s conjecture in [15], i.e. of Van der Waerden conjecture for the mixed discriminant, is an adaptation of Egorychevâ€™s proof in [8]. In contrast, the proofs in [17] and in the present paper have practically nothing in common either with Egorychevâ€™s proof or with Falikmanâ€™s proof in [10].

  1. 1.

    How do we prove the lower bounds?
    We follow the general approach by the present author, introduced in [17].
    We associate with the Minkowski polynomial VğŠsubscriptğ‘‰ğŠV_{{\bf K}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT a sequence of polynomials:

    qn=VğŠ,qiâ¢(x1,â€¦,xi)=âˆ‚nâˆ’iâˆ‚xi+1â¢â€¦â¢âˆ‚xnâ¢qnâ¢(x1,â€¦,xi,0,â€¦,0),1â‰¤iâ‰¤nâˆ’1.formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘‰ğŠformulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–superscriptğ‘›ğ‘–subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¥1â€¦subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘–0â€¦01ğ‘–ğ‘›1q_{n}=V_{{\bf K}},q_{i}(x_{1},...,x_{i})=\frac{\partial^{n-i}}{\partial x_{i+1}...\partial x_{n}}q_{n}(x_{1},...,x_{i},0,...,0),1\leq i\leq n-1.italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG âˆ‚ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n - italic_i end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT â€¦ âˆ‚ italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , 0 , â€¦ , 0 ) , 1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ italic_n - 1 .

    Câ¢aâ¢pâ¢(qi)â‰¥Î»â¢(i+1,minâ¡(i+1,aâ¢fâ¢fâ¢(i+1)))â¢Câ¢aâ¢pâ¢(qi+1),1â‰¤iâ‰¤nâˆ’1.formulae-sequenceğ¶ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–ğœ†ğ‘–1ğ‘–1ğ‘ğ‘“ğ‘“ğ‘–1ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘ğ‘–11ğ‘–ğ‘›1Cap(q_{i})\geq\lambda\left(i+1,\min(i+1,aff(i+1))\right)Cap(q_{i+1}),1\leq i\leq n-1.italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) â‰¥ italic_Î» ( italic_i + 1 , roman_min ( italic_i + 1 , italic_a italic_f italic_f ( italic_i + 1 ) ) ) italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_q start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) , 1 â‰¤ italic_i â‰¤ italic_n - 1 .

    Not surprisingly, we do use the (still hard to prove) Alexandrov-Fenchel inequalities to prove this crucial inequality. (In contrast, the H-Stable case in [17] required just the elementary AG inequality).

  2. 2.

    How do we prove the uniqueness?

    The uniqueness proofs in [8] and [15] are critically based on the known characterization of the equality cases in the Alexandrov inequalities for the mixed discriminant. In the case of the Alexandrov-Fenchel inequalities for the mixed volume such a characterization is not known. Luckily, the method of our proof of the lower bound (3) allows us to use the well known characterization of equality in the (much simpler) Brunn-Minkowski inequality. The uniqueness proof in the present paper is very similar to the uniqueness proof in [17]. The fundamental tool in [17] was GÃ¥rdingâ€™s famous (and not hard to prove) result on the convexity of the hyperbolic cone.

The main difference between the two problems is that the value and the gradient of determinantal polynomials can be exactly evaluated in deterministic polynomial time. The case of the Minkowski polynomials VğŠsubscriptğ‘‰ğŠV_{{\bf K}}italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT requires some extra care. We now give an overview of the main points:

4 Open Problems

  1. 1.

    Prove that for â€œrandomâ€ convex sets Vâ¢(K1,â€¦,Kn)Câ¢aâ¢pâ¢(VğŠ)â‰¤n!nnâ¢Oâ¢(1)ğ‘‰subscriptğ¾1â€¦subscriptğ¾ğ‘›ğ¶ğ‘ğ‘subscriptğ‘‰ğŠğ‘›superscriptğ‘›ğ‘›ğ‘‚1\frac{V(K_{1},\ldots,K_{n})}{Cap(V_{{\bf K}})}\leq\frac{n!}{n^{n}}O(1)divide start_ARG italic_V ( italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , â€¦ , italic_K start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_C italic_a italic_p ( italic_V start_POSTSUBSCRIPT bold_K end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG â‰¤ divide start_ARG italic_n ! end_ARG start_ARG italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG italic_O ( 1 ) with high probability. This is true for the permanents of random matrices with nonnegative entries.

  2. 2.

    The most important question is whether or not there exists a FPRAS algorithm for the mixed volume (or for the mixed discriminant). We conjecture that the answer is negative.

  3. 3.

    Another important open problem is whether or not our mixed volume generalization (10) of Schrijverâ€™s lower bound on the number of perfect matchings in regular bipartite graphs [27], [29], [17] is asymptotically sharp.
